7:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":["Living in ","Belgrano"]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none text-muted-foreground leading-relaxed","children":[["$","p","0",{"className":"mb-4","children":["Belgrano is where Buenos Aires stops feeling like a capital city and starts feeling like a European suburb. The tree-lined streets of Belgrano R (the residential section) are wide, quiet, and dotted with single-family houses — a rarity in apartment-dominant BA. It's the neighborhood where expats transition from visitors to residents","."]}],["$","p","1",{"className":"mb-4","children":["Many families with children end up here for the excellent schools (Lincoln School, Belgrano Day School), safe streets, and parks. Belgrano C (commercial) around Cabildo avenue offers shopping, restaurants, and services. The area's Chinatown on Arribeños street is one of the city's most interesting culinary destinations — the best Chinese and Asian food in Argentina","."]}],["$","p","2",{"className":"mb-4","children":["The downside is distance — Belgrano is further from the city center than Palermo or Recoleta, and the social scene is quieter. But the Subte D line connects you to downtown, and the lower rents mean you can afford a much larger apartment. For expats who've done the Palermo circuit and want something more settled, Belgrano is the natural next step.",""]}]]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"mt-12","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm
